REPORT:
Below is a snippet of patient's discharge summary and a following instruction from healthcare professional.

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: [INSERT NAME]
Gender: Male
Age: 29
Medical Record Number: [INSERT NUMBER]

Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to our outpatient clinic for a delayed diagnosis of proximal hamstring injury due to a soccer injury 3 years earlier. The patient reported previous consultations with multiple healthcare professionals with no relief of symptoms. The chief complaint was daily pain underneath the buttock, worsened by physical activity, longer walking, and while sitting. Impairment in the athlete's performance with muscle weakness of the hamstrings led to severe restrictions in daily life.

Physical examination revealed significant tenderness along the proximal hamstring tendons and at the ischial tuberosity with no palpable defect at the hamstring insertion at the ischial tuberosity. Active and passive range of motion (ROM) of hip and knee were unremarkable. An ischial tuberosity apophyseal fracture with a 7 × 3 centimeter (cm) large, displaced fragment was detected through plain radiographs and computed tomography (CT) of the pelvis. Magnet resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis showed nonunion and displacement of approximately 1 cm.

Due to daily complaints, surgery was performed. Fourteen years after the initial trauma, an open excision of the large bony fragment and an open repair of the proximal hamstring tendons was performed. The patient was placed in a prone position and surgical dissection was performed. Following the excision of the fragment and debridement of local fibrous tissue, refixation of the proximal hamstring tendons was performed using 3 suture anchors at the ischial tuberosity. Postoperatively, the patient was mobilized on crutches, underwent prescribed physical therapy, and wore a hard frame hip and knee brace for 6 weeks. 

Outcome:
Ninety-four points were scored on the Perth Hamstring Assessment Tool nine months postoperatively. At 12-month postoperative follow-up the patient reported satisfaction and was able to perform normal daily activities and engage in various physical activities, including volleyball, beachvolleyball, hiking, kite-surfing, climbing, and skiing.

Discharge Diagnosis:
Proximal hamstring injury due to a soccer injury with ischial tuberosity apophyseal fracture and nonunion.

Discharge Instructions:
Follow up with the outpatient clinic as scheduled. No weight-bearing activity for six weeks following surgery. Continue crutches use for six weeks from the date of discharge. Wear the prescribed hard frame hip and knee brace for six weeks. Follow the prescribed physical therapy program.
[Discharge Summary End]

[Instruction Begin]
What was the patient's diagnosis and treatment plan for a delayed proximal hamstring injury with an ischial tuberosity apophyseal fracture, according to the discharge summary?
[Instruction End]

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Hospital Course:

The patient, a 53-year-old woman, presented to our institution with abdominal pain and diarrhea. Abdominal examination was concerning for significant epigastric tenderness in the right upper quadrant and left lower quadrant. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrated a large amount of simple-appearing free fluid within the abdomen and mucosal edema throughout the small bowel.

Diagnosis:

Angioedema of the small bowel, secondary to lisinopril usage, was the more likely diagnosis.

Treatment:

Lisinopril was discontinued, after which the patient started improving clinically with diminution of symptoms. The patient’s hypertension was treated with amlodipine.

Follow-Up:

At the two-week outpatient follow-up, the patient had been symptom-free and continued to do well.

Final Diagnosis:

Angioedema of the small bowel, secondary to lisinopril usage, with normal C1-inhibitor and serum C4 level.

Discharge Summary:

This 53-year-old woman was discharged from our institution after presenting with abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient was diagnosed with angioedema of the small bowel, secondary to lisinopril usage, with normal C1-inhibitor and serum C4 level. The patient's lisinopril was discontinued, and her hypertension was treated with amlodipine. At the two-week outpatient follow-up, the patient had been symptom-free and continued to do well.
[Discharge Summary End]

[Discharge Summary Begin]
DISCHARGE SUMMARY:

Patient Name: [REDACTED]
Medical Record Number: [REDACTED]
Date of Admission: [REDACTED]
Date of Discharge: [REDACTED]

Hospital Course:
The 45-year-old male patient was admitted to the hospital with a history of suicidal attempt by ingestion of about 50 gm of highly concentrated copper sulphate. The patient had vomited bluish gastric contents after ingestion and later complained of body weakness and abdominal pain. On examination, he was conscious, rational and hemodynamically stable. The respiratory, abdominal and nervous system examination was unremarkable. The patient developed severe epigastric pain with loose stools and melaena 48 hours after admission. The haemoglobin dropped to 6.3 g/l with evidence of intravascular haemolysis. By day 4 he developed severe aspiration pneumonia and was electively intubated and ventilated. The patient was diagnosed with erosive gastropathy and acute kidney injury, for which he was managed with supportive care and chelation therapy with oral penicillamine. Haemodialysis was initiated on day 5 and continued on every other day basis for 10 days until renal functions started recovering. The patient required mechanical ventilation for eight days in the intensive care unit.

Discharge Diagnosis:
The patient was diagnosed with copper sulphate poisoning with erosive gastropathy, intravascular haemolysis, acute kidney injury and sepsis.

Hospital Course Summary:
The patient responded well to treatment and the supportive care measures provided during his hospital stay. The patient showed no further complications on follow up and was eventually discharged after 25 days of hospital stay.

Instructions Upon Discharge:
The patient was advised to follow up with his primary care physician and to continue taking any prescribed medications as per their instructions. The patient was also counselled about the potential risks and dangers related to suicide attempts and urged to seek professional help in case of any future suicidal ideation.
[Discharge Summary End]

Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: Not Provided

Date of Discharge: Not Provided

Hospital Course:
A 66-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with a maculopapular skin rash that gradually progressed to involve all the extremities with generalized pruritus. She reported loss of appetite and weight loss in the last month. The patient was diagnosed with mastocytosis and primary pulmonary involvement in extra-nodal marginal zone lymphoma of MALT origin (MALT lymphoma). The patient's skin rash and pruritus resolved spontaneously over the course of the next six weeks. More tests and exams were performed to evaluate systemic involvement in mastocytosis and assess associated hematologic and solid organ malignancies. The patient had a video-assisted thoracoscopic wedge resection of the largest solid lung nodule. Repeat CT chest at six and 12 months after resection failed to show any evidence of recurrence or metastasis, and the patient continued to be symptom-free.

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Hospital Course:
The 51-year-old female patient had a CT scan which revealed a 13 cm mass in the left perirenal space with multiple lymphadenopathy in the left para-aortic space. The patient underwent ultrasonography-guided biopsy of the mass which appeared to be a benign lymphoproliferative lesion. Mass excision was performed which included the left kidney and the enlarged para-aortic lymph nodes without residual masses. Pathological examination confirmed that the lesion was Castleman Disease (hyaline-vascular type) involving the perinephric and paraaortic lymph nodes. 

Follow-Up:
Regular follow-up was conducted with abdominopelvic CT scans and after a disease-free state of 52 months, multiple enlarged lymph nodes were found in follow-up CT scans. A three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy was performed which resulted in a partial response with decrease of lymph node size less than 1 cm. On follow-up CT scans 12 months after radiotherapy, the patient had no evidence of disease. 

Discharge Summary:
1. Diagnosis:
The patient was found to have Castleman Disease (hyaline-vascular type) involving the perinephric and paraaortic lymph nodes. 

2. Hospital Course:
The patient underwent mass excision which included the left kidney and the enlarged para-aortic lymph nodes without residual masses. Follow-up was conducted regularly with abdominalpelvic CT scans.

3. Follow-Up:
There was a disease-free state after the mass excision for 52 months but multiple enlarged lymph nodes were found on follow-up CT scans. Three-dimensional conformal radiotherapy was performed resulting in a partial response with decrease of lymph node size less than 1 cm. There was no evidence of disease on follow-up CT scans 12 months after radiotherapy. 

4. Medications:
No medications were prescribed at discharge. 

5. Discharge Instructions:
None at this time. 

6. Follow-Up Plan:
The patient will have regular follow-up appointments to continue monitoring for any signs of Castleman Disease.
[Discharge Summary End]

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Hospital Course:
The 65-year-old male patient presented with drug-refractory, symptomatic atrial arrhythmias and underwent a pace-and-ablate strategy. A biventricular pacemaker was implanted with a coronary venous LV lead, which had to be deactivated due to positional phrenic nerve stimulation. This led to the recurrence of heart failure. An LV endocardial lead was successfully placed transatrially, but the patient presented with worsening breathlessness after 9 months. TOE showed severe mitral regurgitation with tethering of the posterior mitral valve leaflet to the LV lead. The LV lead was consequently removed and a new LV lead was implanted via the coronary sinus.

Discharge Summary:
The patient presented with atrial arrhythmias and underwent several procedures, including the implantation of a biventricular pacemaker with a coronary venous LV lead, and subsequently transatrial placement of an LV endocardial lead. However, he presented with severe mitral regurgitation after 9 months, which required the removal of the LV lead. A new LV lead was successfully implanted via the coronary sinus. The patient had a good clinical response at 6 months follow-up.
[Discharge Summary End]

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the emergency department with sharp epigastric pain radiating to the back associated with nausea and diarrhea. Past medical history included cholecystectomy in 2010, depression, and IBS-D. On examination, she had epigastric tenderness without rebound. No organomegaly was noted. Laboratory testing confirmed elevated lipase levels. Symptoms were attributed to acute pancreatitis due to the use of eluxadoline for IBS-D. After symptomatic management, the patient's symptoms subsided and she was discharged home in a stable condition. 

Discharge:
The patient was discharged home with instructions to avoid using eluxadoline for IBS-D in the future. She was advised to continue using her other medications - bupropion and oral contraceptive pills - as prescribed. Her symptoms had resolved except for vague abdominal discomfort after meals which was characteristic of her IBS-D. It was suggested that she follow up with her primary care physician for further management of her IBS-D and any potential future episodes of pancreatitis.
[Discharge Summary End]

REPORT:

[Discharge Summary Begin]
Discharge Summary:

Patient Name: N/A
Age: 70 years
Sex: Male

Chief Complaint:
SCA (Sudden Cardiac Arrest) with typical chest pain

History of Present Illness:
The patient, a 70-year-old male, presented at the emergency room in December 2011 with SCA and typical chest pain. The electrocardiogram conducted after cardiopulmonary resuscitation showed ST elevation in the anterior leads. The patient had a previous history of coronary risk factors, including hypertension, smoking, and diabetes, and had undergone CABG 4 years ago in another hospital.

Hospital Course:
After the SCA, the patient was promptly referred to the catheterization room for primary percutaneous coronary intervention. The initial physical examination revealed absent pulses in both upper and lower extremities. A blind-puncture at the left brachial artery was performed to conduct coronary angiography, but the 035" hydrophilic soft terumo wire (Terumo, Tokyo, Japan) did not pass the LSCA. The transbrachial peripheral angiography showed a total occlusion of LSCA, but the graft from the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) to mid-left anterior descending artery (LAD) was patent. After passing 014" guide wire (Pilot, Abbott, Santa, Clara, CA, USA) through the lesion, the LSCA was progressively dilated by a 2.0×20 balloon (Lacrosse, Goodman Medical Ireland Ltd., Galway, Ireland) inflated at 16 atm and a 4.0×20 mm balloon (Lacrosse, Goodman Medical Ireland Ltd., Galway, Ireland) at 18 atm. A 7.0×24 mm stent (Coroflex Blue, Braun Vascular Systems, Berlin, Germany) was deployed at the LSCA. Transbrachial coronary angiography showed three vessels with CAD presenting significant atherosclerotic stenosis of proximal LAD, major obtuse marginal artery, and mid-right coronary artery. The peripheral angiography showed total occlusion of the right common iliac artery and left external iliac artery. Due to the patient's unstable vital signs, an attempt was made to insert the intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) via the left brachial artery, which was successfully located in the descending thoracic aorta. However, the IABP was not operating properly and had to be removed. The patient was stabilized with medical treatment after percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) but, unfortunately, had sequela of ischemic brain damage.

Conclusion:
The patient was diagnosed with Sudden Cardiac Arrest with typical chest pain and had a previous medical history of hypertension, smoking, and diabetes. The patient had undergone CABG 4 years ago. The treatment involved percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) after which the patient was stabilized but had sequela of ischemic brain damage.
[Discharge Summary End]

[Instruction Begin]

[Instruction End]

The electrocardiogram conducted after cardiopulmonary resuscitation showed ST elevation in the anterior leads.The patients had a previous history of coronary risk factors, including hypertension, smoking, and diabetes, but had undergone CABG 4 years ago in another hospital.Nitrome声Hospital Course:�After the SCAs, the patient was promptly referred to coronary catheterization room for primary percutaneous coronary intervention.  The initial physical examination revealed absent pulses in both upper and lower extremities.A blind-puncture at a left brachial artery was performed to conduct coronary angiography, however, 035" hydrophilic soft terumo wire (Terumo, Tokyo, Japan) did not pass the LSCC..  The transbrachia peripheral angioplography showed a total occlusion of LACA,But the graft from the left internal mammary artery (LIMA) to mid-left anterior descending artery(LAD) was patent.After passing 014" guide wire ƞ" (Pilot, Abbott, Santa, Clara, CA, USA) through the lesion, The LLCA was progressively dilated by a 2.0×20 balloon (lacrosse, Goodman Medical Ireland Ltd., Galway, Ireland) inflated at 16 atm and then a 4·0 ×20 mm balloon Ʀ and  a 4·6 mm Balloon (McGill Medical Irish Ltd.Glasgow, Scotland) at 18 atmm.However,  the IABP was not operating properly and had to be removed.  The patients was stabilized with medical treatment after periprocedural transluminal angio-plasty(PTA) but, unfortunately, had sequela of ischemic brain damage.
